advice: If the child can drink and feed, advise the caregiver to continue to offer fluids and food to the child on the way to the health facility.
If the child is still breastfeeding, advise the mother to continue breastfeeding. Offer the breast more frequently and for a longer time at each feed.
If the child is not breastfeeding, advise the caregiver to offer water to drink and some easy -to-eat food.
If the child has diarrhoea, help the caregiver start giving ORS solution right away. Sometimes the ORS solution can help the child stop vomiting. Then the child can take other oral medicines.

To keep the child warm, cover the child, including the child’s head, hands, and feet with a blanket. Keep the child dry if it rains. If the weather is cold, advise the caregiver to put a cap on the child’s head and hold the child close to her body.

If the child is hot with fever, covering the body too much will raise the body temperature. A light cloth or blanket may be enough to cover the child with fever if the weather is warm. If the body becomes very hot, advise the caregiver to remove even the light blanket.
